Synthetic data shuffling accelerates the convergence of federated learning under data heterogeneity

Abstract

In federated learning, data heterogeneity is a critical challenge. A straightforward solution is to shuffle the clientsâ€™ data to homogenize the distribution. However, this may violate data access rights, and how and when shuffling can accelerate the convergence of a federated optimization algorithm is not theoretically well understood. In this paper, we establish a precise and quantifiable correspondence between data heterogeneity and parameters in the convergence rate when a fraction of data is shuffled across clients. We prove that shuffling can quadratically reduce the gradient dissimilarity with respect to the shuffling percentage, accelerating convergence. Inspired by the theory, we propose a practical approach that addresses the data access rights issue by shuffling locally generated synthetic data. The experimental results show that shuffling synthetic data improves the performance of multiple existing federated learning algorithms by a large margin.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is emerging as a fundamental distributed learning paradigm that allows a central server model to be learned collaboratively from distributed clients without ever requesting the client data, thereby dealing with the issue of data access rightsÂ [20, 12, 41, 35]. One of the most popular algorithms in FL is FedAvgÂ [20]. A server distributes a model to the participating clients, who then update it with their local data for multiple steps before communicating it to the server, where the received client models are aggregated, finishing one round of communication. Two main challenges in FedAvg optimization are 1) large data heterogeneity across clients and 2) limited available data on each clientÂ [20].

Data heterogeneity refers to differences in data distributions among participating clientsÂ [12]. Existing works typically characterize its impact on the convergence of FedAvg using bounds on the gradient dissimilarity, which suggests a slow convergence when the data heterogeneity is highÂ [14, 19]. Many efforts have been made to improve FedAvgâ€™s performance in this setting using advanced techniques such as control variatesÂ [14, 2, 23] and regularizersÂ [43]. Although these algorithms have demonstrated great success in many applications, they are insufficient under high data heterogeneityÂ [48]. On the other hand, many researchersÂ [51, 44] observed that simply augmenting the dataset on each client with a small portion of shuffled data collected from all clients can significantly accelerate the convergence of FedAvg. However, it has yet to be well understood when and, in particular, by how much shuffling can accelerate the convergence.

Another challenge arises when the amount of available data on each client is limited, especially when the number of classes or tasks is large. High-capacity deep neural networks (DNN) usually require large-scale labelled datasets to avoid overfittingÂ [10, 37]. However, labelled data acquisition can be expensive and time-consumingÂ [37]. Therefore, learning with conditionally generated synthetic samples has been an active area of researchÂ [34, 8, 37, 49, 52, 24]. Adapting the framework of using synthetic data from centralized learning to FL is not trivial due to the unique properties of FL, such as distributed datasets, high communication costs, and privacy requirementsÂ [12].

In this work, we provide a more precise and quantifiable correspondence between data heterogeneity and the parameters in the convergence rate. Specifically, we prove that reducing data heterogeneity by shuffling in a small percentage of data from existing clients gives a quadratic reduction in the gradient dissimilarity and can lead to a super-linear reduction in the number of communication rounds. The number of rounds is reduced by a factor greater than the shuffle percentage. Further, we show that the theory holds in both strongly-convex functions and non-convex DNN-based FL.

While our theory suggests that shuffling even a small percentage of clientsâ€™ data can reduce the required communication rounds to reach certain accuracy, collecting real data from clients goes against the goal of protecting privacy in FL. Therefore, we propose a more practical framework Fedssyn where we shuffle a collection of synthetic data from all the clients at the beginning of FL (see Fig.Â 1). Each client learns a client-specific generator with a subset of its local data and generates synthetic data. The server then receives, shuffles, and redistributes the synthetic data to each client. This process only happens once and has no requirements on the FL algorithm that is being used.

Contributions: We summarize our main results below:

  • â€¢

    We rigorously analyze the relation between data heterogeneity and the parameters in the convergence rate in FedAvg. We prove that shuffling a small percentage of data across clients gives a quadratic reduction in the gradient dissimilarity and can lead to a super-linear reduction in the number of communication rounds. We empirically verify the tightness of the theory on strongly convex and DNN-based non-convex functions.

  • â€¢

    We present a practical framework Fedssyn, that shuffles locally generated synthetic data and can be coupled with any FL algorithms.

  • â€¢

    We empirically demonstrate that using Fedssyn on top of several popular FL algorithms reduces the number of communication rounds and improves Top-1 accuracy. Results hold across multiple datasets, different levels of data heterogeneity, number of clients, and participation rates.

1.1 Related work

Federated optimization: FL is a fast-growing fieldÂ [12, 41]. We here mainly focus on works that address the optimization problems in FL. FedAvgÂ [20] is one of the most commonly used optimization techniques. Despite its success in many applications, its convergence performance under heterogeneous data is still an active area of researchÂ [14, 42, 16, 32, 44, 23]. Theoretical results suggest that the drift caused by the data heterogeneity has a strong negative impact on FedAvg convergence. However, in practice, the impact of data heterogeneity is often less detrimental than the theory has predicted, especially in DNN-based FLÂ [14, 32, 4].

Several lines of work have been proposed to reduce the impact of data heterogeneity, including regularizersÂ [32], control variates for correcting gradientsÂ [14, 2, 23, 30], and decoupled representation and classificationÂ [7, 26, 48]. However, such methods are insufficient to conquer high client heterogeneity and can hardly achieve comparable accuracies as in the IID scenariosÂ [48]. Other works proposed to use sophisticated aggregation strategies on the server via ensemble distillationÂ [25], momentumÂ [13], normalizationÂ [43], or adaptivityÂ [31].

Synthetic data-based FL: Many works attempt to improve the performance of FL algorithms using synthetic datasetsÂ [46, 52, 49, 24, 8, 40]. These works can be grouped into 1) client-generatorÂ [46, 24, 40], where synthetic data is generated locally and then communicated to the server for the server model updating, and 2) server-generatorÂ [52, 49], where a centralized generator is used to assist in updating the server and/or client model. Compared to the existing synthetic data-based FL methods, our proposed framework is simple to use, requires less additional communication cost, and has removed many other complicated components, as shown in TableÂ A.1.

Generative models: Generative models can be trained to mimic the underlying distribution of complex data modalities such as text and imagesÂ [9]. Among the existing approaches, Generative Adversary Network (GANs) have achieved great success in generating high-quality, smooth, and sharp imagesÂ [38, 50, 15]; however, GANs are challenging to trainÂ [33], which can especially be an issue in FL as each client has limited dataÂ [20]. Recently, diffusion modelsÂ [11] have attracted much attention due to the high diversity and quality of the generated samplesÂ [34], training efficiencyÂ [11], and consistency in hyperparameter choices across datasetsÂ [34]. Therefore, we study to use DDPM as our local generator in this paper.

Differentially private learning in neural networks: Differential privacy (DP) bounds the influence of any single input on the output of machine learning algorithms to avoid information leakage about the input dataÂ [29, 36, 1]. Differentially private stochastic gradient descent (DP-SGD) achieves DP guarantee by clipping gradients and adding random noiseÂ [29], which has been applied for training FL algorithmsÂ [29] and generative modelsÂ [45, 5, 47]. However, this paper aims to analyze the relationship between data heterogeneity and convergence rate from the optimization perspective. Using both DP-generator and DP-FL algorithms complicates the problem as it introduces many other variates, such as the clipped gradients and DP-noise. Therefore, we leave this as our future work.

2.1 Motivation

In real-world FL applications, each client often collects data individually, so data heterogeneity across clients is unavoidableÂ [6, 20]. Experimental studies often simulate data heterogeneity by limiting the number of classes (tasks) on each client by splitting data into shards (Shards-sampling)Â [20, 48] or using Dirichlet sampling based on a concentration parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha (Dirichlet-sampling)Â [2, 25, 23]. It has been observed in both sampling schemes that under high data heterogeneity, replacing a small percentage of the clientâ€™s data, e.g. 10%, with data shuffled across clients, can enormously reduce the reached optimal errorÂ [44, 51]. However, this empirically vast improvement due to shuffling has yet to be well explained by theory. Therefore, we aim to fill this gap in the following sections.

To formally describe the data heterogeneous scenario, we assume each client has access to data with distribution ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} that is non-iid across clients and we denote by ğ’Ÿ~:=â‹ƒiğ’Ÿiassign~ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\tilde{\mathcal{D}}:=\bigcup_{i}\mathcal{D}_{i} the uniform distribution over the joint data. We can now model our shuffling scenario where the sever mixes and redistributes a small pğ‘p fraction of the data by introducing new client distributions ğ’Ÿ^i:=(1âˆ’p)â€‹ğ’Ÿi+pâ€‹ğ’Ÿ~assignsubscript^ğ’Ÿğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘~ğ’Ÿ\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{i}:=(1-p)\mathcal{D}_{i}+p\tilde{\mathcal{D}} for a shuffling parameter pâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘01p\in[0,1]. If p=0ğ‘0p=0, the local data remains unchanged, and if p=1ğ‘1p=1, the data is uniform across clients. This formulation is consistent with the Shards-sampling and Dirichlet-sampling as we can choose pğ‘p to match the corresponding degree of data heterogeneity.

2.2 Theoretical analysis

We extend the analysis fromÂ [19, 44, 17], which qualitatively characterizes the impact of data heterogeneity on FedAvg, to incorporate a more quantifiable relation between data heterogeneity and parameters in the convergence rate. Namely, shuffling pğ‘p fraction of data to each client reduces gradient dissimilarity quadratically and can significantly accelerate the convergence when the stochastic noise is small. We describe this in detail next.

An additional non-convex experiment using MNISTÂ [22] that shows the accumulative effect between local steps and shuffling is shown in the appendix (Fig.Â B.2).

Fig.Â 2 (a) shows the influence of shuffling when we vary the stochastic noise given a fixed Î¶2superscriptğœ2\zeta^{2} and stepsize. We observe that in the high-noise regime, shuffling gives a smaller reduction on the optimal error than when Ïƒ2=0superscriptğœ20\sigma^{2}=0 as ğ’ªâ€‹((1âˆ’p)â€‹Ïƒ2+pâ€‹Ïƒ~2Ïµ)ğ’ª1ğ‘superscriptğœ2ğ‘superscript~ğœ2italic-Ïµ\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{(1-p)\sigma^{2}+p\tilde{\sigma}^{2}}{\epsilon}\right) tends to dominate no matter how much data we shuffle. Fig.Â 2 (b) shows the influence of shuffling when Ïƒ2=0superscriptğœ20\sigma^{2}=0 and ğ’ªâ€‹(Lpâ€‹Ï„â€‹(1âˆ’p)â€‹Î¶Ïµ)ğ’ªsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğœ1ğ‘ğœitalic-Ïµ\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\sqrt{L_{p}}\tau(1-p)\zeta}{\sqrt{\epsilon}}\right) dominates the convergence. We tune the step size for each experiment to reach the target accuracy (Ïµ=1.1â‹…10âˆ’6italic-Ïµâ‹…1.1superscript106\epsilon=1.1\cdot 10^{-6}) with the fewest rounds. The theoretical number of rounds required to reach Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, indicated by the vertical bars, were determined by calculating Rp=ApÏµ+Bpsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘subscriptğ´ğ‘italic-Ïµsubscriptğµğ‘R_{p}=\frac{A_{p}}{\sqrt{\epsilon}}+B_{p}, where Apsubscriptğ´ğ‘A_{p} is the coefficient that depends on Î¶2superscriptğœ2\zeta^{2} and Lpsubscriptğ¿ğ‘L_{p}. To estimate Apsubscriptğ´ğ‘A_{p}, we measure the number of rounds to reach different accuracies and fit a linear line between Rpsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘R_{p} and 1Ïµ1italic-Ïµ\frac{1}{\sqrt{\epsilon}}. The fitted lines are shown in the Appendix. Fig.Â 2 (b) shows that the empirical speedup matches the theoretical speedup as the observed and theoretical number of rounds to reach the target accuracy are very close. For better visualization, we compare the theoretical and estimated ratio in Fig.Â 2 (c) given Ïƒ2=0superscriptğœ20\sigma^{2}=0. Fig.Â 2(c) shows the ratio between the coefficient ApAp=0subscriptğ´ğ‘subscriptğ´ğ‘0\frac{A_{p}}{A_{p=0}} which boils down to ğ’ªâ€‹(Lpâ€‹Î¶pLp=0â€‹Î¶p=0)ğ’ªsubscriptğ¿ğ‘subscriptğœğ‘subscriptğ¿ğ‘0subscriptğœğ‘0\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\sqrt{L_{p}}\zeta_{p}}{\sqrt{L_{p=0}}\zeta_{p=0}}\right). The nearly matching lines in Fig.Â 2 (c), especially when pğ‘p is small, verify our theoretical statement about the impact of data heterogeneity on the convergence parameters. When pğ‘p is large, Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} and the constant term tend to dominate the convergence. A linear line between Rpsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘R_{p} and 1Ïµ1italic-Ïµ\frac{1}{\sqrt{\epsilon}} is incomplete to explain the convergence rate.

3 Synthetic data shuffling

We have theoretically and empirically verified the benefit of adding shuffled data to each client. However, collecting data from all the clients goes against the goal of protecting user privacy in FL. To still enjoy the benefit of shuffling and alleviate information leakage, we propose a practical framework that shuffles the aggregated synthetic data from all the clients (see Fig.Â 1).

We denote the client dataset, client generated synthetic dataset, and shuffled synthetic dataset by ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}, ğ’Ÿ~isubscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘–\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i}, and ğ’Ÿ~~ğ’Ÿ\tilde{\mathcal{D}} (in accordance with the notation for the data distributions in Sec.Â 2). On each client iğ‘–i, we uniformly subsample Ïâ‹…niâ‹…ğœŒsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–\rho\cdot n_{i} data points from the local dataset ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}, given Ïâˆˆ(0,1]ğœŒ01\rho\in(0,1] and ni=|ğ’Ÿi|subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–n_{i}=|\mathcal{D}_{i}|, which we use to locally train a class-conditional generator. Using a subset rather than the entire dataset can alleviate the exposure of the class distribution from each client. Given the trained local generator, we generate ğ’Ÿ~isubscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘–\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i} with |ğ’Ÿ~i|=n~subscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘–~ğ‘›|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i}|=\tilde{n} synthetic data, matching the class frequency in the subset. We assume that all the clients are willing to send their synthetic dataset to the server. The server then shuffles the aggregated synthetic datasets â‹ƒiâˆˆ[N]ğ’Ÿ~isubscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘subscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘–\bigcup_{i\in[N]}\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i} and distributes the data uniformly among the clients. In practice, when the number of synthetic data is large, their statistical dependency is negligible, and the synthetic data can be considered nearly iid. Reflecting this, we denote the partitioned shuffled synthetic dataset as ğ’Ÿ~sâ€‹isubscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘–\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{si} on each client, and the proportion of the synthetic dataset is calculated as p:=n~ni+n~assignğ‘~ğ‘›subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–~ğ‘›p:=\frac{\tilde{n}}{n_{i}+\tilde{n}} (see Algorithm I).

We then run FL algorithms with the updated dataset on each client ğ’Ÿiâˆªğ’Ÿ~sâ€‹isubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{si}. Our framework has no requirements for the FL algorithm, so we here briefly describe one of the most common FL algorithms: FedAvgÂ [20], as shown in Algorithm II. FedAvg mainly has two steps: local model updating and server aggregating. We initialize the server with a model ğ’™ğ’™\boldsymbol{x}. In each communication round, each participating client SâŠ†[N]ğ‘†delimited-[]ğ‘S\subseteq[N] receives a copy of the server parameter ğ’™ğ’™\boldsymbol{x} and performs Kğ¾K steps local updates (e.g. Kğ¾K steps SGD). The updated model ğ’šisubscriptğ’šğ‘–\boldsymbol{y}_{i} is then sent to the server. FedAvg calculates the server model by averaging over the received client models, finishing one round of communication. We repeat this for Rğ‘…R rounds or until the target accuracy is achieved.

4 Experimental setup

We demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100Â [21] image classification tasks. We leave the test set on the server to evaluate the accuracy of the server model. We partition the training dataset using Dirichlet distribution with a concentration parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha to simulate the heterogeneous scenarios followingÂ [25]. The smaller the Î±ğ›¼\alpha, the higher data heterogeneity among the clients. We choose Î±âˆˆ{0.01,0.1}ğ›¼0.010.1\alpha\in\{0.01,0.1\} in our study as they are commonly usedÂ [48, 25]. Each client has a local dataset, kept fixed and local throughout the communication rounds.

We use DDPMÂ [11] with the same architecture asÂ [11] as our class-conditional generator on each client due to its training efficiency and consistency in hyperparameter choices across datasetsÂ [34]. We assume that all the clients participate in training DDPM by using 75% of their local data as the training data. Each client trains DDPM with a learning rate of 0.00010.00010.0001, 100010001000 diffusion time steps, 256256256 batch size, and 500500500 epochs. These hyperparameters are the same for all experiments. Once the training finishes, each client simulates n~=50000N~ğ‘›50000ğ‘\tilde{n}=\frac{50000}{N} (there are 50K training images in CIFAR10 and CIFAR100) synthetic images with the label, which are then sent to the server. The server aggregates and shuffles the received synthetic dataset and then distributes it to each client equally. This finishes the synthetic data generation and distribution process.

We then perform federated optimization. We experiment with some of the popular FL algorithms including FedAvgÂ [20], FedProxÂ [32], SCAFFOLDÂ [14], FedDynÂ [2], and FedPVRÂ [23]. We use VGG-11 for all the experiments. We train the FL algorithm with and without using the synthetic dataset to demonstrate the speedup obtained from using synthetic dataset quantitatively.

We experiment with full and partial clients participation. We use Nâˆˆ{10,40,100}ğ‘1040100N\in\{10,40,100\} as the number of clients and Câˆˆ{0.1,0.2,0.4,1.0}ğ¶0.10.20.41.0C\in\{0.1,0.2,0.4,1.0\} as the participation rate. For partial participation, we randomly sample Nâ‹…Câ‹…ğ‘ğ¶N\cdot C clients per communication round. For all the experiments, we use a batch size of 256256256, 101010 local epochs, and the number of gradient steps 10â€‹ni25610subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–256\frac{10n_{i}}{256}. We tune the client learning rate from {0.01,0.05,0.1}0.010.050.1\{0.01,0.05,0.1\} with the local validation dataset (10%percent1010\% of the training data). The learning rate is the same along the communication rounds. The results are given as an average of three repeated experiments with different random initializations. The code is publically available at https://github.com/lyn1874/fedssyn.

5 Experimental results

We demonstrate the performance of Fedssyn on top of five popular FL frameworks here. Our main findings are: 1) Sampling shuffled synthetic data into each client can significantly reduce the number of rounds used to reach a target accuracy and increase the Top-1 accuracy. 2) The performance across different FL algorithms is nearly identical when we use the shuffled synthetic data. 3) The quantified gradient dissimilarity and stochastic noise in DNN match the theoretical statements.

5.1 Communication efficiency and accuracy

We first report the required number of communication rounds to reach the target accuracy in TableÂ 1. The length of the grey and red colour bar represents the required number of rounds to reach accuracy mğ‘šm when the local dataset is ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} and ğ’Ÿiâˆªğ’Ÿ~sâ€‹isubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{si}, respectively. The speedup is the ratio between the number of rounds in these two settings. We observe that adding shuffled synthetic data to each client can reduce the number of communication rounds to reach the target accuracy for all the FL algorithms, datasets, data heterogeneity levels, and different participation rates. Additionally, we see the speedup is small when the number of clients is high on CIFAR100, e.g. N=100ğ‘100N=100. One of the main reasons is that the quality of the generator drops as the number of images used to train the local generator is small (375 images), but the number of classes is large (100).

We next report the Top-1 accuracy in Fig.Â 3. To verify that the accuracy improvement is mainly due to the changes in the convergence parameters rather than the increased number of images on each client, we compare experiments where the local dataset is ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}, the mixture between local real and local synthetic data ğ’Ÿiâˆªğ’Ÿ~isubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i}, the mixture between local real and shuffled synthetic data ğ’Ÿiâˆªğ’Ÿ~sâ€‹isubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{si}, We also compare them with the centralised experiments using the centralised real and synthetic data.

Fig.Â 3 shows that using the shuffled synthetic data can significantly improve the Top-1 accuracy in nearly all the cases compared to other baselines, which indicates that the vast performance improvement is mainly due to the changes in the parameters in the convergence rate rather than the increased number of images in each client. Specifically, we observe that the performance differences between different levels of data heterogeneity for the same dataset are nearly negligible (the red bar vertically) when we add the shuffled synthetic data, which indicates that the quality of the generator DDPM is less sensitive to the imbalanced data as it aims at learning the underlying data distribution. We also see that the Top-1 performance is decreasing as we increase the number of clients, especially for the CIFAR100 dataset with 100 clients (the red bar horizontally). We can improve this performance by generating more synthetic images for the CIFAR100 dataset, as 1000 training images (500 real+500 synthetic) per client is insufficient to learn 100 classes.

5.2 Sensitivity analysis

We here depict the sensitivity of FedAvg on the quality of the synthetic data using CIFAR10 in Fig.Â 4. Fig.Â 4 (a) shows that the number of images for training DDPM has a substantial impact on FL performance, which is reasonable, as we can acquire higher-quality synthetic images if we use more images to train the generator. Fig.Â 4 (b) shows that when the number of clients is low, the synthetic images extracted from the early training checkpoints already have high quality. However, when the number of clients is high, the longer we train the generator, the better FL performance we can achieve. Fig.Â 4 (c) shows that using DDPM is slightly better than GAN-based generators (NDAÂ [38], DGAN and DCrGANÂ [50], and StyleGANÂ [15]) in terms of accuracy.

5.3 Parameters in the convergence rate

We here investigate the impact of using shuffled synthetic data on the parameters in the convergence rate for DNN-based FedAvg in Fig.Â 5. We use CIFAR10, 10 clients with full participation, Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1, and Ïâ‹…ni=4500â‹…ğœŒsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–4500\rho\cdot n_{i}=4500. We observe that when p=0.06ğ‘0.06p=0.06, though the stochastic noise Ïƒ^p2superscriptsubscript^ğœğ‘2\hat{\sigma}_{p}^{2} remains similar, Î¶^p2superscriptsubscript^ğœğ‘2\hat{\zeta}_{p}^{2} has reduced by half and we improve the Top-1 accuracy by 20%. When p=0.5ğ‘0.5p=0.5, we obtain a much smaller Ïƒ^p2superscriptsubscript^ğœğ‘2\hat{\sigma}_{p}^{2} and Î¶^p2superscriptsubscript^ğœğ‘2\hat{\zeta}_{p}^{2}. Consequently, we achieve an even better Top-1 accuracy than the IID experiment. However, the parameters in Fig.Â 5 (b) and (c) are evaluated with different server models ğ’™p,rsubscriptğ’™ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ\boldsymbol{x}_{p,r}, so it is less comparable to LemmaÂ 1 where they are measured with the same server model. Therefore, we evaluate the gradient dissimilarity Î¶^p2superscriptsubscript^ğœğ‘2\hat{\zeta}_{p}^{2} and stochastic noise Ïƒ^p2superscriptsubscript^ğœğ‘2\hat{\sigma}_{p}^{2} using ğ’Ÿiâˆªğ’Ÿ~sâ€‹isubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{si} and the corresponding Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} and Î¶2superscriptğœ2\zeta^{2} using ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} with the same server model ğ’™rsubscriptğ’™ğ‘Ÿ\boldsymbol{x}_{r} in each round in Fig.Â 5 (d). We use Î´ğ›¿\delta to represent how well the distribution of the synthetic data matches the real dataset. See AppendixÂ D for a better explanation. We observe that (1âˆ’p)â€‹Ïƒ21ğ‘superscriptğœ2(1-p)\sigma^{2} dominates over other terms in the effective stochastic noise, which means the first term in the convergence rate for non-convex function in CorollaryÂ I can be simplified as ğ’ªâ€‹((1âˆ’p)â€‹Ïƒp2â€‹Lpnâ€‹Ïµ2)ğ’ª1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘2subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘›superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{(1-p)\sigma_{p}^{2}L_{p}}{n\epsilon^{2}}\right) in this experimental setup. For Î¶^p2superscriptsubscript^ğœğ‘2\hat{\zeta}_{p}^{2}, the empirical result also matches the theory. These results show that in this experimental setup, adding shuffled synthetic dataset reduces both stochastic noise and function dissimilarity, and lead to a greater accuracy improvement.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we have rigorously analyzed the relation between data heterogeneity and the parameters in the convergence rate in FedAvg under standard stochastic noise and gradient dissimilarity assumptions. While previous works usually qualitatively represent data heterogeneity with gradient dissimilarity, we proposed a more quantifiable and precise characterization of how the changes in the data heterogeneity impact the parameters in the convergence rate using shuffling.

Our work paves the way for a better understanding of the seemingly unreasonable effect of data heterogeneity in FL. The theoretical findings inspired us to present a more practical framework, which shuffles the locally generated synthetic dataset, achieving nearly as good performance as centralized learning, even when the data heterogeneity is high in some cases. Our work reveals the importance of data distribution matching in FL, opening up future research directions.

Appendix A Extra related work comparison

Local ğ’¢isubscriptğ’¢ğ‘–\mathcal{G}_{i} and Server ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} means local and server generators for generating synthetic datasets. ğ’Ÿ~â€‹(r)~ğ’Ÿğ‘Ÿ\tilde{\mathcal{D}}(r) means the synthetic data is transmitted between the client and server at every communication round, which can incur extra communication costs. Updating the server model with the synthetic data at every communication round ğ’™â†ğ’Ÿ~â†ğ’™~ğ’Ÿ\boldsymbol{x}\leftarrow\tilde{\mathcal{D}} requires the synthetic data to be of high qualityÂ [25, 34], as updating the server model with low-quality synthetic data or synthetic data with a different distribution than the actual local data may discard the valuable information it has learned.

Appendix B Extra experimental details

Experimental results on MNIST dataset We consider a distributed multi-class classification problem on MNIST dataset given (Ai,ğ’ƒi)subscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptğ’ƒğ‘–(A_{i},\boldsymbol{b}_{i}) as the dataset on worker iğ‘–i with:

ğ’ši=softmaxâ€‹(Aiâ€‹ğ’™),Aiâˆ¼â„niÃ—784,ğ’™âˆˆâ„784Ã—10,ğ’šiâˆˆâ„niÃ—10formulae-sequencesubscriptğ’šğ‘–softmaxsubscriptğ´ğ‘–ğ’™formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptğ´ğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–784formulae-sequenceğ’™superscriptâ„78410subscriptğ’šğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–10\boldsymbol{y}_{i}=\text{softmax}(A_{i}\boldsymbol{x}),\quad A_{i}\sim\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}\times 784},\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{784\times 10},\boldsymbol{y}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}\times 10} (B.1a)
fiâ€‹(ğ’™):=1niâ€‹âˆ‘j=1ni110â€‹âˆ‘k=110(ğ’ƒiâ€‹jâ€‹kâ€‹logâ¡(ğ’šiâ€‹jâ€‹k))assignsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ’™1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–110superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜110subscriptğ’ƒğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğ’šğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜f_{i}(\boldsymbol{x}):=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\frac{1}{10}\sum_{k=1}^{10}(\boldsymbol{b}_{ijk}\log(\boldsymbol{y}_{ijk})) (B.1b)

We construct the training dataset by subsampling 1024 images from each class from the MNIST training dataset. We use the test dataset to evaluate the performance of the server model (10000 images). We consider two scenarios for splitting the dataset across workers: 1) iid, where each worker has a similar number of images across classes 2) split by class, where each worker can only see images from a single class. We set 10 workers, and each worker has 1024 images ni=1024subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–1024n_{i}=1024. We experiment with a different number of local epochs Eğ¸E on each worker and shuffling percentage pğ‘p. For a given pğ‘p, we subsample niâ€‹psubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘n_{i}p data points randomly from each worker and allocate them in ğ’Ÿ~~ğ’Ÿ\tilde{\mathcal{D}}. We then shuffle ğ’Ÿ~~ğ’Ÿ\tilde{\mathcal{D}} and distribute it equally to all workers such that each worker has niâ€‹psubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘n_{i}p shuffled data points and niâ€‹(1âˆ’p)subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–1ğ‘n_{i}(1-p) local data points. We choose to control the stochastic noise ÏƒÂ¯2superscriptÂ¯ğœ2\bar{\sigma}^{2} by adding Gaussian noise to every gradient:

ğ’šiâ†ğ’šiâˆ’Î·â€‹(âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’ši)+s),sâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,ÏƒÂ¯2784)formulae-sequenceâ†subscriptğ’šğ‘–subscriptğ’šğ‘–ğœ‚âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ’šğ‘–ğ‘ similar-toğ‘ ğ’©0superscriptÂ¯ğœ2784\boldsymbol{y}_{i}\leftarrow\boldsymbol{y}_{i}-\eta(\nabla f_{i}(\boldsymbol{y}_{i})+s),\quad s\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\frac{\bar{\sigma}^{2}}{784}) (B.2)

Fig.Â B.2 shows the results. When the dataset is IID across workers, adding the shuffled dataset to each worker does not influence the learning speed. This agrees with the lemmas that we have shown in the main text. When the dataset is non-iid across workers, shuffling a small percentage of the local dataset can highly improve the convergence, especially when the number of local epochs is high, e.g. E=5ğ¸5E=5. We can achieve a slightly better speedup when the stochastic noise is non-zero, which is most of the cases in the neural network training where we use mini-batch SGD.

Extra figure for Sec.Â 2.3 Fitted lines between the number of iterations and 1Ïµ1italic-Ïµ\frac{1}{\sqrt{\epsilon}}.

Limitations As our proposed framework requires the uploading of the synthetic data to the server, it is less appropriate for tasks that deal with substantially sensitive information, such as patient records. A possible way to improve the utility of our proposed framework is to make the generator and federated learning algorithms differential private. We leave this as our future work.

Appendix C Experimental results on dSprites dataset

In this section, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed framework on the dSprites datasetÂ [27]. We here perform a slightly different synthetic data generation process. Rather than using the DDPMÂ [11], we generate the synthetic dataset on each client with Î²ğ›½\beta-VAEÂ [3]. We then aggregate and shuffle the collected synthetic dataset on the server and distribute them to clients following the same procedure as described in Sec.Â 3 and Sec.Â 4.

C.1 Training details

The dSprites datasetÂ [27] contains three different types of shapes with different colours, scales, rotations, and locations.

Data preparation We first randomly select 10% of the images from the dSprites dataset to formulate the test set. We leave the test set on the server to evaluate the performance of the server model. For the rest of the dataset, we split them among 12 clients (N=12ğ‘12N=12) based on the four spatial locations (top-left, bottom-left, top-right, or bottom-right) and three shapes (square, ellipse, or heart) such that each client only sees a single type of shape from one of the four pre-defined locations. The number of images on each client is the same (ni=55296subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–55296n_{i}=55296). We consider each shape as a class and perform shape classification.

Synthetic data generation We use Î²ğ›½\beta-VAE with the same architecture asÂ [3] following a publicly available implementation222https://github.com/1Konny/Beta-VAE/. We train an individual Î²ğ›½\beta-VAEÂ [3] on each client with batch size 256, latent dimension 10. To evaluate the sensitivity of the federated learning optimization on the quality of the generator, we train the generator using different fractions of data Ïâ€‹niğœŒsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–\rho n_{i} with ÏğœŒ\rho being {1%,2%,4%,8%,16%,32%,64%,100%}percent1percent2percent4percent8percent16percent32percent64percent100\{1\%,2\%,4\%,8\%,16\%,32\%,64\%,100\%\} on each client. When Ï=100%ğœŒpercent100\rho=100\%, we train a Î²ğ›½\beta-VAE with the entire dataset from each client.

Many works have demonstrated that the latent variables in Î²ğ›½\beta-VAE can encode disentangled representative features of the input imagesÂ [3, 27, 18], and manipulating a single latent dimension can result in substantial changes of the corresponding factor of variation, e.g. scale, in the output from the decoder. Therefore, we can obtain diverse synthetic images by interpolating the extracted latent representations. To achieve this, we extract the averaged latent representations for each class, specifically the mean of the posterior distribution Î¼csubscriptğœ‡ğ‘\mu_{c}Â [3]. We then sample n~isubscript~ğ‘›ğ‘–\tilde{n}_{i} latent codes from the Gaussian distribution parameterised by mean Î¼csubscriptğœ‡ğ‘\mu_{c} and standard deviation 111. The sampled latent codes are then passed as the input for the decoder from Î²ğ›½\beta-VAE to generate synthetic images. We collect the synthetic images from all the clients, which are then shuffled and distributed equally to each client such that the local dataset on each client is pâ€‹ğ’Ÿi+(1âˆ’p)â€‹ğ’Ÿ~sâ€‹iğ‘subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–1ğ‘subscript~ğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘–p\mathcal{D}_{i}+(1-p)\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{si}. An example of the generated synthetic image is shown in Fig.Â C.2. With the updated dataset on each client, we follow the same procedure as documented in Sec.Â 4 to perform federated optimization with FedAvgÂ [28]. We make this dataset publicly available at https://github.com/mlolab/fedssyn-synthetic-dSprites.

C.2 Discussion

We show the sensitivity of FedAvgâ€™s performance on the quality of the synthetic images in Fig.Â C.1. The left image shows that training the VAE longer does not necessarily provide better quality synthetic images when we use fewer training images. However, when we use more training images (higher ÏğœŒ\rho), the images extracted from early checkpoints, e.g. 50% epochs, are already of high quality. We observe a similar pattern in the right image in Fig.Â C.1, where the number of training images has a more substantial influence on the performance of FedAvg than the number of generated synthetic images.
